page.title: List of serial killers by country

revision.text:
{{pp-semi-indef}} This is a list of '''notable [[serial killer]]s, by the country''' where most of the murders were committed. {{TOC right}}
==Convicted serial killers by country==
===Afghanistan=== * [[Abdullah Shah]]: killed at least 20 travelers on the road from [[Kabul]] to [[Jalalabad]] serving under [[Zardad Khan]]; also killed his wife; executed on 20 April 2004.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news |title=Former Afghan commander executed |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3662935.stm |work=BBC News |date=2004-04-27 |accessdate=20 August 2009}}</ref>
===Argentina=== * [[Florencio Fernández]]: also known as "The Argentine Vampire"; killed 15 women in his hometown of [[Monteros]] during the 1950s. * [[Cayetano Santos Godino]]: also known as "Petiso Orejudo" ("Big Eared Midget"); at 16, killed four children in 1912; died in prison in 1944.<ref name=CA>{{cite web|url=http://www.casoabierto.com/reportajes/cronica-negra/cayetano-santos-godino-la-historia-del-petiso-orejudo.html |title=Cayetano Santos Godino, la historia del Petiso Orejudo |accessdate=2008-09-12 |last=Cabezas López |first=Carlos |date=2007-09-16 |work=Caso Abierto |language=Spanish |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080801214210/http://www.casoabierto.com/reportajes/cronica-negra/cayetano-santos-godino-la-historia-del-petiso-orejudo.html |archivedate=2008-08-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Cayetano Domingo Grossi]]: the first serial killer in Argentine history; murdered 5 of his newborn children between 1896 and 1898; executed 1900.<ref>{{citeweb|url=http://www.acciontv.com.ar/soca/polis/enero13/grosi.htm|title=El fusilamiento de Cayetano Grossi (1900)|access-date=12 November 2015|publisher=AccionTV}}</ref> * [[Francisco Antonio Laureana]]: also known as "The Satyr of [[San Isidro, Buenos Aires|San Isidro]]"; murdered 15 women from 1974 to 1975, raping 13 of them; killed in a shootout with the police in 1975.<ref>Kablan, Pablo (2014): [http://www.diariopopular.com.ar/notas/182535-francisco-laureana-el-serial-san-isidro "Francisco Laureana, the serial of San Isidor"], article from February 2, 2014 in the "Diario Popular".</ref> * [[Yiya Murano]]: also known as "The Poisoner of [[Monserrat, Buenos Aires|Monserrat]]", poisoned three women in [[Buenos Aires]]. * [[Robledo Puch]]: also known as "The Death Angel" and "The Black Angel"; killed 11 people before his arrest in 1972; sentenced to [[life imprisonment]] in 1980.<ref name="lanacion">{{cite web |url = http://www.lanacion.com.ar/Archivo/nota.asp?nota_id=785598|title = Robledo Puch: el ángel negro|author=La Nación|date = 5 March 2006 |accessdate = 7 April 2014}}</ref>
===Australia=== * [[David and Catherine Birnie]]: responsible for the "Moorhouse Murders"; couple from the suburban [[Perth]] area who murdered four women in 1986.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kidd |first=Paul B |title=The Birnies - 2. A Serial Killer in Perth |work=CourtTV CrimeLibrary |publisher=Courtroom Television Network, LLC. |date=12 February 2007 |url=http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/partners/birnie/1_index.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081123125648/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/partners/birnie/2.html |archivedate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> * [[Gregory Brazel]]: [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] man who shot a woman to death in a 1982 armed robbery, and murdered two prostitutes in 1990.<ref name=killerpayout>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,20409851-5006785,00.html|title=Killer gets compensation payout|work=[[The Australian]]|date=14 September 2006|access-date=|author=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060915121802/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,20867,20409851-5006785,00.html|archive-date=2006-09-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref name=killerlist>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/heraldsun/story/0,21985,20673356-661,00.html|title=Killer caught with jail list|work=[[Herald Sun|Sunday Herald Sun]]|date=13 October 2006|access-date=|author=}}</ref> * [[John Bunting (serial killer)|John Bunting]], [[Robert Wagner (serial killer)|Robert Wagner]] and [[James Vlassakis]]: also known as the "Bodies in the Barrels Murders"; convicted of the [[Snowtown murders]] of 12 people between 1992 and 1999.<ref name="haydon trial">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Bodiesinbarrels-trial-not-over/2004/12/19/1103391631199.html|title=Bodies-in-barrels trial not over|agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]]|date=19 December 2004|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=11 January 2014}}</ref> * [[Robert Francis Burns]]: confessed to eight killings; hanged in [[Ararat, Victoria|Ararat]] in 1883.<ref>http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/198269401?searchTerm=Robert%20francis%20burns&searchLimits=</ref> * [[Clarke brothers|Thomas and John Clarke]]: [[bushranger]] brothers who robbed railroad stations; killed five police officers; the Felons Apprehension Act of 1886, which allowed bushrangers to be killed on sight, was created because of them; both hanged 1867.<ref>http://www.anzlhsejournal.auckland.ac.nz/pdfs_2005/Eburn.pdf</ref> * [[Eric Edgar Cooke]]: also known as the "Night Caller"; killed at least 8 people and attempted to kill many more; last person to be hanged in [[Western Australia]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.postnewspapers.com.au/20030201/news/002.shtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030202114507/http://www.postnewspapers.com.au/20030201/news/002.shtml|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2 February 2003|author=Christian, Bret|work=Post Newspapers|accessdate=2006-09-21|title=Police decoy used in killer hunt sting|df=dmy-all}}</ref> * [[John Leslie Coombes]]: killed two men in 1984 and one woman in 2009 around the Victoria area.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/triple-killer-to-die-in-jail-for-murder-that-ought-never-have-happened-20110826-1jddd.html|title=Triple killer to die in jail for murder that 'ought never have happened'|date=2011-08-26|work=The Age|access-date=2017-09-03|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[Bandali Debs]]: convicted of murdering two police officers and two prostitutes in the 1990s.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/11/09/3061726.htm Man charged 15 years after prostitute's murder]</ref> * [[Paul Denyer]]: also known as the "Frankston Killer"; murdered three women in 1993 in the [[Melbourne]] suburb of [[Frankston, Victoria|Frankston]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/national/killers-family-dont-let-him-out/news-story/59e38892e8170309ccd633d1da3ffca4?sv=c839876f55e2e282e956202a2e18d4b5|title=Serial killer's family: Don't let him out|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aussiecriminals.com.au/high-profile-criminals/paul-charles-denyer-the-frankston-serial-killer/|title=Paul Charles Denyer -The Frankston Serial Killer|date=2012-04-20|work=Aussie Criminals and Crooks|access-date=2018-01-28|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[Peter Dupas]]: serving three life sentences for multiple murder and rape charges in Victoria.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2004/08/12/1092102597125.html?from=storylhs Call for second life term for murderer Dupas] ''[[The Age]]'', 13 August 2004</ref> * [[Kathleen Folbigg]]: murdered four of her infants between 1991 and 1999.<ref>{{cite news | first=Julie | last=Szego |author2=Stephen Cauchi | title=Killing them softly | date=30 August 2003 | url =http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/08/29/1062050669977.html | work =[[The Age]] | accessdate = 14 September 2008}}</ref> * [[Leonard Fraser]]: also known as the "Rockhampton Rapist"; convicted of killing four women in [[Rockhampton, Queensland]].<ref>{{cite journal| last =Bassingthwaighte| first =Ted | title =From Sexual Predator to Murderer| journal =Police news| publisher =[[New South Wales Police Association]]| date = November 2006| url =http://www.pansw.org.au/PolNews/Nov38-52.pdf| accessdate = 2 January 2007 | format = – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?q=author%3A+intitle%3AFrom+Sexual+Predator+to+Murderer&as_publication=Police+news&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup>| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050615215035/http://pansw.org.au/PolNews/Nov38-52.pdf| archivedate = 15 June 2005}}</ref> * [[John Wayne Glover]]: also known as the "Granny Killer"; killed six elderly women on Sydney's [[North Shore (Sydney)|North Shore]]; committed suicide in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gibson|first1=Jano|title=Granny killer found dead in cell|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/granny-killer-found-dead-in-cell/2005/09/09/1125772681493.html|accessdate=9 October 2015|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=9 September 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Dwyer|first1=Erin|title=Mystery woman pays for killer's funeral|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/mystery-woman-pays-for-killers-funeral/2005/09/17/1126750168519.html|accessdate=9 October 2015|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=18 September 2005}}</ref> * [[Caroline Grills]]: also known as "Auntie Thally"; a serial [[Poison#Uses of poison|poisoner]] of five family members in [[New South Wales]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/National/Murder-tried-and-true/2005/02/10/1107890341655.html|title=Murder, tried and true|publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=11 February 2003|accessdate=2008-01-16}}</ref> * [[Paul Steven Haigh]]: sentenced to life imprisonment without parole for the murders of seven people in Victoria in the late 1970s.<ref>[http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/serial-killer-wins-right-to-seek-parole-20110419-1dml5.html killer wins right to seek parole]</ref> * [[Matthew James Harris]]: strangled a friend's brother, a female friend, and a male neighbor to death over five weeks in 1998 in [[Wagga Wagga]].<ref>{{cite AustLII|NSWSC|285|2000|litigants=R v Matthew James Harris |date=7 April 2000 |courtname=auto}}.</ref> * [[Thomas Jeffries]]: Tasmanian [[penal colony]] escapee responsible for the murders of five people; executed in 1826.<ref>Thomas Jeffries convict No. 3634, conduct record, State Archives of Tasmania.</ref> * [[Frances Lydia Alice Knorr|Frances Knorr]]: also known as the "Baby Farming Murderess"; English-born baby farmer who killed 3 infants; executed 1894.<ref>[http://www.cv.vic.gov.au/stories/felon-families-/9300/felon-families-/ Felon families: Stories of women prisoners and their families] National Trust of Australia (Victoria)</ref> * [[Eddie Leonski]]: also known as the "Brownout Strangler"; United States Army soldier who killed three women in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]; executed in 1942.<ref>{{cite news|title=Melbourne Police hunt "Brownout" Strangler |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/231786070|accessdate=16 March 2017|work=The Sun|date=20 May 1942|location=Sydney, NSW|page=3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Leonski, Enigma In Life And In Death, Carries His Secret To Grave |url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/168972547 |accessdate=16 March 2017 |work=Truth|date=15 November 1942|location=Sydney, NSW|page=14}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Killed To Show His Strength|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/75783558|accessdate=16 March 2017|work=Mirror|date=19 April 1952|location=Perth, WA|page=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Robinson|first1=Russell|title=Macabre and detailed hangman's journal reproduced in detail for True Crime Scene|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/law-order/macabre-and-detailed-hangmans-journal-reproduced-in-detail-for-true-crime-scene/news-story/a98b17a1bc653a9f2e034ac32873781b?sv=c73ce64e6658e0bf838435a046bd3579|website=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=News Corporation|accessdate=26 December 2017}}</ref> * [[John Lynch (serial killer)|John Lynch]]: also known as the "[[Berrima, New South Wales|Berrima]] Axe Murderer"; killed ten people from 1835 to 1841.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=nVJD6V0XAtwC&pg=PT32&lpg=PT32&dq=john+lynch+murderer#v=onepage&q=john%20lynch%20murderer|title=Australia's Serial Killers|work=google.com.au}}</ref> * [[William MacDonald (serial killer)|William MacDonald]]: also known as the "Mutilator"; English immigrant who killed at least five men between June 1961 and April 1963 throughout Sydney.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/macdonald/monster_2.html | title = William "The Mutilator" Macdonald: The Making of a Monster | accessdate = 28 October 2010 | last = Kidd | first = Paul B. | date = 2010 | work = William "The Mutilator" Macdonald | publisher = Turner Entertainment Networks | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110811041741/http://www.trutv.com/library/crime/serial_killers/weird/macdonald/monster_2.html | archive-date = 2011-08-11 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref> * [[John and Sarah Makin]]: late 19th century [[baby farming|baby farmers]] who killed and buried 12 children at a succession of their homes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adbonline.anu.edu.au/biogs/AS10317b.htm|title=Makin, John (1845 - 1893)|publisher=[[Australian Dictionary of Biography]]|year=2005|accessdate=20 December 2010}}</ref> * [[Malachi Martin (murderer)|Malachi Martin]]: convicted of killing [[Jane Macmanamin]] and suspected of murdering four additional people as well as being implicated in the suspicious death of his mother; hanged at the [[Adelaide Gaol]] in 1862.<ref>Martin's marriage certificate shows this spelling, while on that certificate he signed his name "Malacky" (1858 marriage certificate indexed by Births, Deaths and Marriages South Australia at Book 317, Page 541). On his petition to the Governor in December 1862 Martin signed his name "Malaky Martin" (Malachy Martin's petition to the Governor & Executive Council of South Australia, GRG 24/6/1862/1215). In oral tradition the name is pronounced in a way that indicates it should be spelt "Malachy" rather than the Biblical "Malachi". John Bowyer Bull, who had met Malachy, mentions him in his memoirs, and although he spells the name several ways, they are all closer to "Malachy" than to "Malachi" (J.B. Bull, unpublished manuscript ''The Life of John Bowyer Bull, The Australian Bushman & Explorer, 1838-1894'', PGR 507/3, pp 62-65).</ref> * [[Backpacker Murders|Ivan Milat]]: killed at least seven tourists in [[Belanglo State Forest]], [[New South Wales]], which became known as the "Backpacker Murders"; suspected in similar disappearances in [[City of Newcastle|Newcastle]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lennon|first1=Troy|title=Twenty five years ago the first victims of Backpacker Killer Ivan Milat were found in Belanglo Forest|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest-twenty-five-years-ago-the-first-victims-of-backpacker-killer-ivan-milat-were-found-in-belanglo-forest/news-story/f4a31abad223faa68d8d73ca054d297e|accessdate=26 January 2018|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=19 September 2017}}</ref> * [[Dan Morgan (bushranger)|Dan Morgan]]: also known as "Mad Dog"; violent bushranger who killed three people from 1864 to 1865; killed during a standoff with the Victoria police.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article80953125 |title=BLOODTHIRSTY MORGAN. |newspaper=[[Singleton Argus]] |location=NSW |date=14 June 1924 |accessdate=16 April 2012 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * [[Martha Needle]]: also known as the "Black Widow of [[Richmond, Victoria|Richmond]]," [[Poison#Uses of poison|poisoner]] of four family members and her boyfriend's brother; executed in 1894.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://newdiogenesmelbourne.wordpress.com/2016/04/17/martha-needles-headstone|title=Martha Needle's headstone}}</ref> * [[James Ryan O'Neill]]: abducted and killed two children around Tasmania; suspected of similar murders in the 1960s in several other states.<ref>[http://www.theage.com.au/news/national/beaumonts-documentary-cleared-by-high-court/2006/09/28/1159337285466.html Beaumonts documentary cleared by High Court] [[The Age]] 29 September 2006</ref> * [[Alexander Pearce]]: Irish convict who escaped with seven other convicts from imprisonment; five of them were killed and cannibalised, leaving Pearce the only one left; hanged 1824.<ref>[http://www.australianhistory.org/other-bushrangers.php Alexander Pierce] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101209021729/http://australianhistory.org/other-bushrangers.php |date=9 December 2010 }}. Australian History: Other Bushrangers. killed five in the 1970s, three with accomplice Michael Kitto.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Murderous Butler|url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/nostalgia/crimelibrary/archibaldthomsonhall/themurderousbutler/|publisher=Watford Observer}}</ref> * [[Peter Manuel]]: also known as the "Beast of [[Birkenshaw, North Lanarkshire|Birkenshaw]]"; American-born Scottish murderer of seven, suspected of killing 15; executed in 1958.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hector MacLeod, Malcolm McLeod|title=Peter Manuel, Serial Killer|date=2010|publisher=Mainstream Publishing ebooks|isbn=9781845968830|pages=Chapter 8|edition=ebook|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Dv6G7xTW0FUC&pg=PT25&lpg=PT25&dq=capelrig+Anne+Kneilands#v=onepage&q=capelrig%20Anne%20Kneilands}}</ref> * [[Edward William Pritchard]]: English doctor who poisoned his wife and her mother in 1865; two years earlier their maid had died in a mysterious fire.<ref>Leighton Bruce, [http://heritage.scotsman.com/notoriouscriminalsfeatureseries/A-deadly-bedside-manner.2680240.jp A deadly beside manner], ''[[The Scotsman]]'', 21 November 2005</ref> * [[World's End Murders|Angus Sinclair]]: convicted of the murders of four young women, including the "World's End Murders" in [[Edinburgh]]; believed to have murdered eight.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1309040/Child-killer-gets-life-for-1978-death-of-teenager.html |title=Child killer gets life for 1978 death of teenager |publisher=Daily Telegraph |date=14 June 2001 |accessdate=5 February 2014 |location=London |first=Tara |last=Womersley}}</ref> * [[Peter Tobin]]: rapist and killer of three women between 1991 and 2006; sentenced to life in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8132283.stm|title=Piecing together serial killer Peter Tobin's past|work=BBC News|date=16 December 2009|access-date=9 January 2017}}</ref>
====Wales==== * [[John Cooper (serial killer)|John Cooper]]: also known as "The Wildman" and "The Bullseye Killer"; [[Pembrokeshire]] burglar responsible for the robbery and shotgun double-murders of a brother and sister in 1985 and a couple in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|last=McCarthy|first=James|title='The moment Bullseye revealed the killer': How shotgun killer John Cooper was caught|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/the-moment-bullseye-revealed-killer-6025096|publisher=Wales Online|date=16 September 2013|accessdate=26 May 2014}}</ref> * [[Peter Moore (serial killer)|Peter Moore]]: also known as "The Man in Black"; businessman who killed four men at random in [[North Wales]] in 1995.<ref>{{cite news|title=Flintshire murderer Peter Moore in European Court of Human Rights appeal over life sentence|author=Eleanor Barlow|url=http://www.flintshirechronicle.co.uk/flintshire-news/local-flintshire-news//tm_headline=flintshire-murderer-peter-moore-in-european-court-of-human-rights-appeal-over-life-sentence%26method=full%26objectid=28267583%26siteid=51352-name_page.html|newspaper=The Flintshire Chronicle|date=3 March 2011|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>
====Northern Ireland==== * [[Shankill Butchers]]: The Shankill Butchers was an Ulster loyalist gang—many of whom were members of the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (UVF)—that was active between 1975 and 1982 in Belfast, Northern Ireland. The gang was based in the Shankill area and were responsible for the deaths of at least 23 people, most of whom were killed in sectarian attacks.<ref>[http://www.politics.ie/history/18916-sectarianism-racism-one-same.html Sectarianism – Racism – One and the Same?], politics.ie; accessed 21 December 2015.</ref>
===United States=== {{main|List of serial killers in the United States}}
===Uruguay=== * [[Pablo Goncálvez]]: Spanish-born murderer who killed tennis player [[Patricia Miller (tennis)|Patricia Miller]]'s half-sister and two other women; freed in 2016 but was arrested in 2017 in [[Paraguay]] for carrying an unregistered weapon and a quantity of cocaine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.teledoce.com/telemundo/nacionales/pablo-goncalvez-en-libertad-salio-de-campanero-a-las-2357-del-jueves/|title=Pablo Goncálvez in freedom: he left Campanero at 23:57 on Thursday|publisher=Canal 12|date=24 June 2016|location=Uruguay|access-date=23 December 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com.uy/informacion/paraguay-analiza-expulsion-goncalvez.html|title=Paraguay analyzes the expulsion of Goncálvez|publisher=El País|date=27 June 2017|location=Uruguay|access-date=27 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.elobservador.com.uy/bonomi-paraguay-pidio-informacion-pablo-goncalvez-n1089872|title=Bonomi: Paraguay asked for information "about Pablo Goncálvez"|publisher=El Observador|date=26 June 2017|location=Uruguay|access-date=27 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.subrayado.com.uy/noticias/68137/la-historia-de-pablo-goncalvez-ahora-preso-en-paraguay|title=The story of Pablo Goncálvez, now imprisoned in Paraguay|publisher=Canal 10|date= 25 June 2017|location=Uruguay|access-date=27 June 2017}}</ref>
===Venezuela=== * [[Dorángel Vargas]]: killed and cannibalized at least 10 men between 1997 and 1999 in [[San Cristóbal, Táchira]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The cannibal of the Andes confesses: 'Eating people is like eating pears' |date=2004-11-19 |url=http://www.absurddiari.com/s/llegir.php?llegir=llegir |work=Las Últimas Noticias |accessdate=2008-09-10 |language=Spanish}}</ref>
===Yemen=== * [[Abdallah al-Hubal]]: killed 7 people in 1990 after the Yemeni reunion; fled prison and killed a young couple and three other people in 1998; killed in a shootout with the police.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.tueursenserie.org/article.php?id_article=30 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2007-10-22 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120915095812/http://www.tueursenserie.org/article.php?id_article=30 |archive-date=2012-09-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * [[Zu Shenatir]]: 5th-century Yemeni serial killer.<ref>{{cite web|last=Horberg|first=Karl|title=Into the Abyss|url=http://www.paperstreetprod.com/compendium/archives/text/5intothe.txt|publisher=Paper Street Productions|date=8 May 1997|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050426080712/http://www.paperstreetprod.com/compendium/archives/text/5intothe.txt|archivedate=April 26, 2005}}</ref>
===Zambia=== * [[Mailoni Brothers]]: three brothers who killed at least 12 people from 2007 to 2013 in [[Central Province, Zambia|Central Province]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201306300093.html | title=Zambia: Mailoni Brothers - History of Serial Killers in Zambia (Page 1 of 5) | publisher=allAfrica.com | date=2013-06-29 | accessdate=2014-04-15 | last=Kaluba | first=Austin}}</ref>
==Unidentified serial killers== This is a list of unidentified serial killers. It includes circumstances where a suspect has been arrested, but not convicted.
===Australia=== * [[Bowraville Murders]]: murders of three [[Indigenous Australians|Aboriginal]] children in between 1990 and 1991.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/austory/content/2006/s1733527.htm Australian Story – Truth be Told – Transcript], 2006-09-04, abc.net.au</ref><ref>[http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/02/07/1075854109819.html Lone cop to tell inquest name of killer suspect], By Alex Mitchell, 2004-02-08, The Sun-Herald</ref><ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/cgi-bin/common/printfriendly.pl?http://www.abc.net.au/rn/talks/bbing/stories/s10587.htm ABC Radio National – Background Briefing: 20 July 1997 – The Ghosts Of Bowraville]</ref> * [[Claremont serial murders]]: murders of two young women and the disappearance of a third in 1996 and 1997.<ref>{{cite news|title=Claremont serial killings: Sarah Spiers murder charge for Bradley Robert Edwards|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-02-22/bradley-edwards-charged-with-sarah-spiers-murder/9475258|accessdate=27 February 2018|work=ABC News|date=23 February 2018}}</ref> * [[The Family Murders]]: murder and mutilation of five young men and boys between 1979 and 1983. [[Bevan Spencer von Einem]] was convicted of one murder.<ref>{{cite episode|title=The Butchered Boys|series=Crime Investigation Australia|series-link=Crime Investigation Australia|network=[[Crime & Investigation Network]]|series-no=1|number=16}}</ref> * [[Tynong North and Frankston Murders]]: murders of six females in [[Tynong North, Victoria|Tynong North]] and Frankston between 1980 and 1981.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theage.com.au/national/retired-detectives-back-in-the-hunt-20051121-ge1a2c.html|title=Retired detectives back in the hunt|last=Silvester|first=John|date=2005-11-21|website=The Age|language=en|access-date=2018-09-14}}</ref>
===Belgium=== * [[Brabant killers]]: gang of serial killers who operated in the [[Brabant (province)|Brabant]] province from 1982 and 1985; murdered 28 people and injured 40.<ref>Vice.com Virgile Dall'Armellina , [https://news.vice.com/article/police-are-running-out-of-time-to-catch-the-crazy-brabant-killers Police Are Running Out of Time to Catch the 'Crazy Brabant Killers']</ref><ref name="rtl.be">[http://www.rtl.be/rtltvi/video/170060.aspx Les dernières heures des tueurs du Brabant (2/3)]</ref> * [[Butcher of Mons]]: unidentified serial killer who committed five murders from January 1996 to July 1997 in [[Mons]]. Montenegrin murderer [[Smail Tulja]] is suspected of being the Butcher.<ref>{{cite web|title=On the Trail of an Intercontinental Killer|periodical=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/08/magazine/hunt-for-a-serial-killer.html|accessdate=|last=Nicholas Schmidle|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}} </ref>
===Brazil=== * [[Paturis Park murders]]: also known as the "Rainbow Maniac"; series of 13 gunshot murders of gay men between July 2007 and August 2008 in Paturis Park (''Parque dos Paturis'') in [[Carapicuiba]].<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/12/10/2442827.htm?section=justin "Police hunt suspected serial killer in Brazil" [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] [[Nick Olle]]] Retrieved 5 September 2017.</ref>
===Canada=== * [[Highway of Tears murders|Highway of Tears]]: death and disappearance of around 40 young women in [[British Columbia]] since 1969.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/society/crime-justice/cold-cases-unsolved-crimes-in-canada/bcs-infamous-highway-of-tears.html|title=BC's infamous 'Highway of Tears'|last=Lee|first=Miyoung |date=November 17, 2009|work=CBC Digital Archives|publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=10 December 2009}}</ref> * [[Toronto hospital baby deaths]]: deaths of at least eight babies at Toronto's Hospital for Sick Children in 1980 and 1981 were initially alleged to be digoxin poisonings, a theory which was cast into doubt by new evidence in 2010-2011.<ref>[Dead babies remain a mystery, QMI Agency, Sunday, March 6 http://www.stcatharinesstandard.ca/2011/03/06/dead-babies-remain-a-mystery {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171225035344/http://www.stcatharinesstandard.ca/2011/03/06/dead-babies-remain-a-mystery |date=2017-12-25 }}] Retrieved 24/12 2017</ref>
===Costa Rica=== * [[El Psicópata]]: killed 19 people from 1986 to 1996 in [[Cartago, Costa Rica|Cartago]], [[Curridabat]] and [[Desamparados]]; suspected of other similar crimes.<ref>[http://www.diarioextra.com/2001/febrero/13/sucesos03.html From Jack the Ripper of London to the Ripper of San José] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121031159/http://www.diarioextra.com/2001/febrero/13/sucesos03.html |date=2010-11-21 }} ''Diario Extra'', February 13, 2001</ref>
===Finland=== * [[Hausjärvi Gravel Pit Murders|Järvenpää Serial Killer]]: responsible for the so-called "[[Hausjärvi]] [[Gravel Pit]] Murders"; killed a woman in 1991 and suspected in the disappearance of another in 1993; possibly responsible for other abductions and murders in the 21st century.<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://keski-uusimaa.fi/Uutiset/Arkisto/2008/07/15/Jarvenpaan-sarjamurhaaja-yrittanyt-ehka-uusia-tekonsa2|title=Järvenpää's serial killer perhaps tried new things|author=Malin Jarkko|publisher=Central Uusimaa|date=15 July 2008|accessdate=22 April 2014|language=Finnish}}</ref>
===Germany=== * [[Göhrde Murders]]: two double murders which occurred in the [[Göhrde State Forest]] in 1989; [[Kurt-Werner Wichmann]], a cemetery gardener who committed suicide in 1993, is suspected of committing these murders, as well as other unrelated ones.<ref>{{Citeweb|title=„Göhrde Murders": Perpetrators identified, questions remain|publisher=NDR|url=https://www.ndr.de/nachrichten/niedersachsen/lueneburg_heide_unterelbe/Goehrde-Morde-Taeter-ermittelt-Fragen-bleiben,goehrde184.html|accessdate=28 December 2017|language=German}}</ref> * [[Sewer Murders]]: also called the "Sewage Plant Murders"; the bodies of several adolescents were discovered in sewage treatment plants in the Frankfurt Rhine-Main in the 1980s.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ns-aOQ_A_gs Film contribution, Kriminalreport Hessen.]</ref>
===India=== * [[Beer Man]]: murdered seven people in south [[Mumbai]] between October 2006 and January 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/beer-man-acquitted-in-second-murder-case-too/story-yG21TyRav3e80e9SlETFlM.html |title='Beer Man' acquitted in second murder case too |last=Iyer |first=Vignesh |date=July 12, 2008 |website= |publisher=hindustantimes |access-date=May 23, 2017 |quote=}}</ref> * [[Stoneman]]: responsible for 13 murders in [[Kolkata]] in 1989.<ref>https://www.hindustantimes.com/india/the-elusive-stoneman-of-kolkata/story-BQBcCHfk87WvoLp2LSCKRN.html</ref>
===Italy=== * [[Monster of Florence]]: committed eight murders of couples in a series of 16 between 1968 and 1985. Giancarlo Lotti and Mario Vanni were convicted of four of the murders, but this conviction has been widely criticized.<ref>{{Cite news |first=David |last=Lohr |authorlink=David Lohr |title=The Monster of Florence |url=http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/predators/monster_florence/10.html |publisher=[[Crime Library]] |accessdate= |page=10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140403090508/http://www.crimelibrary.com/serial_killers/predators/monster_florence/10.html |archivedate=2014-04-03 |df= }}</ref> * [[Monster of Udine]]: killed at least 4 victims in the [[Province of Udine]], [[Italy]].<ref>{{cite web|title=In un ventennio 14 omicidi e 3 arresti|url=http://messaggeroveneto.gelocal.it/udine/cronaca/2012/01/27/news/in-un-ventennio-14-omicidi-e-3-arresti-1.3113223|website=Messaggero Veneto EDIZIONE UDINE|accessdate=18 December 2014|language=Italian|date=27 January 2012}}</ref>
===Japan=== * [[Paraquat murders]]: series of indiscriminate poisonings carried out in Japan in 1985 where twelve people were killed.
===Mexico=== * [[Female homicides in Ciudad Juárez]]: also known as "The dead women of Juárez"; the violent deaths of hundreds of women since 1993 in the northern Mexican city of [[Ciudad Juárez]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Olivera|first=Mercedes|title=Violencia Femicida : Violence Against Women and Mexico's Structural Crisis|journal=Latin American Perspectives|year=2006|volume=33|issue=104|pages=104–114|doi=10.1177/0094582X05286092|url=http://lap.sagepub.com/content/33/2/104.full.pdf|accessdate=2 April 2012}}</ref>
===Namibia=== * [[B1 Butcher]]: murdered at least five women between 2005 and 2007, with all murders related to the [[B1 road (Namibia)|National Road B1]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.namibian.com.na/index.php?id=28&tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=42633&no_cache=1|title=B-1 Butcher: DNA evidence in spotlight|last=Menges|first=Werner|date=29 April 2008|work=[[The Namibian]]}}</ref>
===Poland=== * [[Łódź Gay Murderer]]: murdered 7 homosexual men from 1988 to 1993 in Łódź.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://lodz.wyborcza.pl/lodz/1,35136,7956685,_Zdarzylo_sie_w_Lodzi___Mordowal_gejow_na_Fabrycznym.html|title="It happened in Łódź": Murdered gays on Fabryczny|publisher=Wyborcza.pl|accessdate=15 January 2016|language=Polish}}</ref>
===Portugal=== * [[Lisbon Ripper]]: murdered three women in [[Lisbon]] between 1992 and 1993.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20091027121656/http://geocities.com/verbal_plainfield/coldcases/lisbon.html Unsolved Serial Killings; Portugal, Libson<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Russia=== {{Main|List of Russian serial killers}}
===South Korea=== * [[Hwaseong serial murders]]: series of murders between 1986 and 1991 in [[Hwaseong City|Hwaseong]]; ten women were found raped, bound, and murdered.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Hwaseong Killings Still Baffle Police| author = Kyung-Hyun Nam| work = english.donga.com| date = 2006-04-01| accessdate = 2015-09-09| url = http://english.donga.com/srv/service.php3?biid=2006040104698}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== * [[Bible John]]: thought to be responsible for the deaths of three women in [[Glasgow]], [[Scotland]] in the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=v-NAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3KYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1709,2603592|title=20 years on, the mystery of Bible John still haunts a city|publisher=''[[Evening Times]]''|last=Skelton|first=Douglas|date=10 February 1989|accessdate=22 May 2013}}</ref> * [[Jack the Ripper]]: murdered prostitutes in the East End of London in 1888.<ref>{{Citation|url=http://www.met.police.uk/history/ripper.htm |title=The Enduring Mystery of Jack the Ripper |publisher=London Metropolitan Police |accessdate=31 January 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100204014147/http://www.met.police.uk/history/ripper.htm |archivedate=4 February 2010 }}</ref> * [[Jack the Stripper]]: responsible for the London "[[Hammersmith]] nude murders" between 1964 and 1965.<ref>{{cite news|title=Retro: The mystery of the Jack the Stripper murders|first=James|last=Gates|date=12 March 2012|work=[[Trinity Mirror|Get West London]]|url=http://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/lifestyle/nostalgia/retro-mystery-jack-stripper-murders-5978691|accessdate=4 January 2017}}</ref>
===United States=== {{main|List of serial killers in the United States}}

The '''Mensendieck system''' is a [[Therapy|therapeutic]] movement technique claimed to be both corrective and [[Preventive healthcare|preventive]]. It was invented by a [[Germany|German]] medical doctor Bess M. Mensendieck (c.1866–1959).<ref name="Mosby">[http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/movement+therapy Movement Therapy] at Mosby's Medical Dictionary, 8th edition. 2009. Retrieved July 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09523367.2011.567781 Seeing Your Way to Health: The Visual Pedagogy of Bess Mensendieck's Physical Culture System] by Robin Vedera, ''International Journal of the History of Sport'' Volume 28, Issue 8-9, 2011 Special Issue: Sport and the Visual. * pages 1336-1352. Retrieved July 2012</ref>
She published several books on the subject starting with ''Körperkultur der Frau [Physical Culture of the Woman]'', 1906.<ref>[http://alexander.area24.net/BessMensendieck.htm Bess Mensendieck] Jeroen Staring, ''An Alexander Technique Notebook''. Retrieved July 2012</ref>

{{Infobox Minister | name = Mohammad Ishaq Aloko
محمد اسحاق الکو | image= Aloko in November 2009-cropped.jpg | imagesize=200px | caption=Mohammad Ishaq Aloko in November 2009 | office = [[Attorney General's Office of Afghanistan|Attorney General of]] [[Afghanistan]] | term_start = 24 August 2008 | term_end = 18 October 2014 | president = [[Hamid Karzai]] | predecessor = [[Abdul Jabar Sabet]] | successor = Qaramuddin Shinwari (acting) | birth_date = 1935 | birth_place = [[Kandahar Province]],(Arghandau) [[Afghanistan]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = Afghan | spouse = | party = | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | religion = [[Islam]] | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Mohammad Ishaq Aloko''' {{lang-ps|محمد اسحاق الکو}}; born 1935) is the [[Attorney General's Office of Afghanistan|Attorney General of Afghanistan]] since August 2008. He was appointed by [[President of Afghanistan|President]] [[Hamid Karzai]] after [[Abdul Jabar Sabit]] was forced to resign from the post. An ethnic [[Pashtun people|Pashtun]], he was born in [[Kandahar Province|Kandahar]], Afghanistan. ==Education== Ishaq completed his middle school in Kandahar Province of Afghanistan. He is also a graduate of the Military High School and the Military Academy of [[Kabul]]. After the [[Soviet war in Afghanistan|Soviet occupation of Afghanistan]], Aloko moved to the Federal Republic of [[Germany]] where he studied Law and Administration.http://www.ago.gov.af/Content%5CAttGenPage%5CAttorneyGeneralBiography.htm{{Dead link|date=July 2010}} ==Work life== Aloko worked as an intelligence officer for former President [[Mohammed Daoud Khan]]. From the early 1980s to the early 2000s he lived in Germany and worked at the Ministry of Justice in the State of [[Hamburg]]. After the fall of [[Taliban]], he returned to Afghanistan. He worked as the First Deputy Attorney Generalhttp://www.voanews.com/english/archive/2006-03/2006-03-28-voa9.cfm?moddate=2006-03-28 and President of the Commission for Guantanamo Detainees. He was also a member of the Advisory Board of the Attorney General. In August 2008, Aloko became the Attorney General of Afghanistan.http://quqnoos.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1495&lang=pashto ==Awards== In 2003, by a Presidential decree Aloko received an award for achieving an exceptional performance in government and for a paper on the affairs of the prosecutor. He also received an honorary Professorship degree in the affairs of the AGO and for successful prosecution by a Presidential decree. ==Personal life== Aloko is since 40 years married. His main place of residence is in Germany, Schleswig-Holstein. He is the father of two sons and one daughter. ==Academic works== Mohammad Ishaq Aloko has written several books. Some of them are: * Daoud Khan De KGB Pa Lamunu Kay (داود خان د کې جي بي په لمنو کې); * D Jalalabad Naghmay (د جلال اباد نغمې); * Putay Tubai (پټې توبې); * Saharona Che Amali Nashwal (ښارونه چې املي نشول); ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Mohammad Ishaq Aloko}} *{{Worldcat id|lccn-n2008-219031}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aloko, Mohammad Ishaq}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Government ministers of Afghanistan]] [[Category:Afghan writers]] [[Category:Pashtun people]] [[Category:People from Kandahar]] [[Category:1935 births]] [[Category:Attorneys General of Afghanistan]] {{Afghanistan-politician-stub}}

{{infobox ethnic group| |group=Nyaw |image= |population=120,000 |popplace=Parts of [[Isan]], Central [[Laos]], Western [[Cambodia]] |rels=[[Theravada Buddhism]] |langs=[[Tai Yo language|Tai Yo]], [[Isan language|Isan]]/[[Lao language|Lao]], [[Thai language|Thai]] [[Khmer language|Khmer]] |related=Other Tai peoples. }}
The '''Lao Nyaw''', '''Thai Nyaw''' or '''Tai Yo''' (Thai/Isan: [[wikt:ไทญ้อ|ไทญ้อ]], {{IPA-th|tʰāj jɔ́ː}}, <small>Isan pronunciation:</small> {{IPA-th|tʰɑj ɲɔː|}}) are an [[ethnic group]] of [[Thailand]], [[Cambodia]] and [[Laos]], scattered throughout the provinces of [[Isan]] such as [[Nong Khai]], [[Sakon Nakhon]], [[Nakhon Phanom]], and parts of [[Bolikhamxai]] and [[Khammouan]] provinces of [[Laos]]. They are also referred to as simply ''Nyaw'' or ''Yaw'', depending on either the Lao, Isan, and Nyaw pronunciation, which all pronounce the initial consonant as {{IPAblink|ɲ}}, or the Thai pronunciation, which pronounces the initial consonant as {{IPAblink|j}}.
==History== The Tai Nyaw believe that they are descendants of people originally from the northernmost part of Laos and Tonkin or immigrants during Tai migrations. Whatever the case may be, their dialect most closely resembles the Lao dialects from the regions east of [[Luang Prabang]]. Legend has it descendants are from the old king of [[Laos]], who migrated after the overthrow and was forced to leave and spread out to neighboring countries for refuge. The Nyaw believed their ancestors are the king's personal guards and extended family.
==Language== {{main|Nyaw language}} The Nyaw language is very similar to the [[Lao language]], which is referred to as the [[Isan language]] in Thailand. It is most similar to the [[Phuthai]] language also spoken within the same regions. Most Nyaw are often also fluent in [[Thai language|Thai]] and [[Lao language|Lao]].
==Religion== The Tai Nyaw practise [[Theravada Buddhism]], but have also maintained their original animist religion. Important to the Nyaw people is the tutelary spirit of the village, known in the dialect as ผู้เจ้า {{IPA-th|pʰuː tɕaw|}}.
==Status==
In Thailand this language group is increasingly becoming integrated into the mainstream Isan language. This is due in large part to a campaign by the Thai government to modernize all Thai people, as well as due to outside influences of television, internet and local radio broadcasts. Most younger members of this northeastern tribal group in Thailand prefer to be called Thai rather than by their traditional tribal group name.
==Headhunters==
Believed to be Nyaw indigenous headhunters who sought other tribes for bounty and sport, It was an honor to retrieve the heads of rival tribes as a trophy. Many traditional families still kept the severed skulls as charms and for use in [[Black Magic]] known as "Kong Dee". After the integration of [[Laos|Lao]], [[Thailand|Thai]] and [[Cambodia]]n mainstream society the head hunts were deemed unacceptable.{{citation needed|date=October 2014}}
==References== <references/> *http://www.seamist.org/peoples/nyaw-thai.shtml *http://khmerling.blogspot.com/2008/02/nya-dialect-collecting-data.html

"Gender" refers to social or cultural distinctions associated with being male or female. Scholars generally regard gender as a [[social construct]]—meaning that it does not exist naturally, but is instead a concept that is created by cultural and societal norms.<ref>{{Cite web|url = Source: Boundless. “Defining Sex, Gender, and Sexuality.” Boundless Psychology. Boundless, 20 Aug. 2015. Retrieved 23 Oct. 2015 from https://www.boundless.com/psychology/textbooks/boundless-psychology-textbook/gender-and-sexuality-15/introduction-to-gender-and-sexuality-75/defining-sex-gender-and-sexuality-294-12829/}}</ref> ''[[Gender binary]]'' is the system of viewing gender as consisting solely of two, opposite categories, termed “male and female”, in which no other possibilities for gender or anatomy are believed to exist. This system is oppressive to anyone who defies their sex assigned at birth, but particularly those who are gender-variant or do not fit neatly into one of the two standard categories.<ref name=":0" /> Gender identity, one’s internal sense of being male, female, neither of these, both, or other genders, is something that everyone has, and not everyone identifies their gender as male or female.<ref name=":0" />
It is important to note that sex, gender, and sexuality are not the same, and that one does not dictate the other. "Sex" is what you are assigned at birth, and is typically based on physical anatomy.<ref name=":0" /> "Sexuality", or sexual orientation, is a person's enduring physical, romantic, emotional, and other form of attraction to others.<ref name=":0" />
== Other genders == There are many different ways to describe one’s gender. ''[[Trans Student Educational Resources]]'' (TSER)<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = LGBTQ+ Definitions {{!}} Trans Student Educational Resources|url = http://www.transstudent.org/definitions|website = www.transstudent.org|accessdate = 2015-10-22}}</ref> gives a breakdown of gender with defining the following terms;
[[Bigender|Bigender:]] Refers to those who identify as two genders.
[[Cisgender]]/cis: Someone who exclusively identifies as their sex assigned at birth.
[[Genderqueer]]/non-binary: An identity commonly used by people who do not identify within the gender binary. Those who identify as genderqueer may identify as neither male nor female, may see themselves as outside of or in between the binary gender boxes, or may simply feel restricted by gender labels.
[[Intersex]]: Describing a person with a less common combination of hormones, socio-emotional, chromosomes, and anatomy that are used to assign sex at birth. This term is not interchangeable with or a synonym for transgender, although some intersex people do identify as transgender.
[[Queer]]: A term for people of marginalized gender identities and sexual orientations who are not cisgender or heterosexual.
[[Transgender]]/trans: Term for those who do not identify or exclusively identify with their sex assigned at birth.
[[Transsexual]]: Term describing someone who undergoes or wants to undergo transition within the gender binary.
It is crucial to know what individuals choose to identify themselves as, and what pronouns they prefer others to use as well. Several terms, such as ''queer'', are used as slurs and may be offensive to some, while others may not mind it.
== Gender norms == Gender norms are the socially acceptable ways of acting out gender, and are learned from birth. People learn what is expected of their gender from what their parents teach them, as well as what they pick up at school, through religious or cultural teachings, in the media, and various other social institutions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Sociology of Gender|url = http://othersociologist.com/sociology-of-gender/|website = The Other Sociologist - Analysis of Difference... By Dr Zuleyka Zevallos|accessdate = 2015-10-22|language = en-US|date = 2014-11-27}}</ref> Many aspects of gender are socially constructed, particularly with regard to gender expression, which is closely monitored and reinforced by society. Many things in society are defined by gender—toys, colors, clothes and behaviors are just some of the more obvious examples. Through a combination of social conditioning and personal preference, by age three most children prefer activities and exhibit behaviors typically associated with their sex.<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.genderspectrum.org/quick-links/understanding-gender/|title = Gender Spectrum|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox language |name=Picard |nativename=Picard |pronunciation= |states= [[France]], [[Belgium]] |speakers= c. 700,000 |date=2008 |ref=Julie Auger, Indiana University, ''“Issues of authenticity, purity, and autonomy in minority languages: What is “real” Picard, and who is an “authentic” speaker?”'', Congress ''Minority and Diasporic Languages of Europe'' , 14-17 Feb. 2003 , Berkeley, US, in Pawel Nowak & Corey Yoquelet (eds.), Berkeley Linguistics Society (BLS 29).
* - in France: ca. 500 000 speakers '''[fr]''' [http://www.encyclopedie.picardie.fr/index.php/Le_picard,_langue_d'o%C3%AFl]
- in Belgium : a rough approximation is about 12% to 15% of people in province of Hainaut, i.e. ca. 150 000 to 200 000 speakers. |familycolor=Indo-European |fam2=[[Italic languages|Italic]] |fam3=[[Romance languages|Romance]] |fam4=[[Western Romance languages|Western]] |fam5=[[Gallo-Romance languages|Gallo-Romance]] |fam6=[[Langues d'oïl|Oïl]] |nation=None |agency=None |minority={{flag|Belgium}} |iso3=pcd |glotto=pica1241 |glottorefname=Picard |lingua=51-AAA-he |map= |notice=IPA }} '''Picard''' is a [[langues d'oïl]] dialect spoken in the northernmost part of France and southern Belgium. Administratively, the area where it is spoken is divided between the French [[Hauts-de-France]] region and the [[Belgium|Belgian]] [[Wallonia]] along the border between the two countries – its traditional core being the districts of [[Tournai]] and [[Mons]], commonly referred to as [[Wallonie Picarde|Walloon Picardy]]. The Picard language group is known by several different names. Residents of [[Picardy]] simply call it '''''picard''''', but it is more commonly known as '''''chti''''' or '''''chtimi''''' in the more populated [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]] ([[Romance Flanders]] around the metropolis of [[Lille]] and [[Douai]], and northeast [[Artois]] around [[Béthune]] and [[Lens, Pas-de-Calais|Lens]]). It is also named '''''rouchi''''' around [[Valenciennes]]; or simply as '''[[patois]]''' by Northerners in general. [[linguistics|Linguist]]s group all of them under the name ''Picard''. In general, the variety spoken in Picardy is understood by speakers in Nord-Pas-de-Calais and vice versa. Today, Picard is usually classified as merely a dialect of French as spoken in France by French linguists, rather than as a standalone language or distinct dialect in its own right, primarily due to French's heavy influence over the centuries when both French ([[Francien language|Francien dialect]]) and Picard were developing from a common [[protolanguage]], [[Vulgar Latin]]. It is also seen as such by many of its speakers. ==Recognition== [[File:Langues_d'oïl_2.svg|thumb|240px|The geographical spread of Picard and Chtimi among the [[Langues d'oïl|Oïl languages]] (other than French) can be seen in shades of green and yellow on this map.]] [[Belgium's French Community]] gave full official recognition to Picard as a regional language along with [[Walloon language|Walloon]], ''[[Lorrain language|Gaumais]]'' ([[Lorraine (région)|Lorraine]]), [[Champenois]] ([[Champagne, France|Champagne]]) and [[Lorraine Franconian|Lorraine German]] in its 1990 decree. The French government has not followed suit and has not recognized Picard as an official regional language (in line with its policy of linguistic unity, which allows for only one official language in France), but some reports have recognized Picard as a language distinct from French. A 1999 report by Bernard Cerquiglini, the director of the ''{{lang|fr|Institut national de la langue française}}'' (National Institute of the French Language) stated:
The gap has continued to widen between French and the varieties of ''[[Oïl languages|langues d'oïl]]'', which today we would call "French dialects"; [[Frainc-Comtou dialect|Franc-comtois]], [[Walloon language|Walloon]], Picard, [[Norman language|Norman]], [[Gallo language|Gallo]], [[Poitevin (language)|Poitevin]], [[Saintongeais]], [[Burgundian language (Oïl)|Bourguignon-morvandiau]], [[Lorrain language|Lorrain]] must be accepted among the regional [[languages of France]]; by placing them on the list [of French regional languages], they will be known from then on as ''langues d'oïl''.Bernard Cerquiglini, ''[http://www.dglflf.culture.gouv.fr/lang-reg/rapport_cerquiglini/langues-france.html The Languages of France]'', Report to the Minister of National Education, Research and Technology, and the Minister of Culture and Communication, April 1999
Even if it has no official status as a language in France, Picard, along with all the other languages spoken in France, benefits from actions led by the Culture Minister's General Commission on the French Language and the Languages of France (''la Délégation générale à la langue française et aux langues de France''). ==Origins and dialectic variations== [[File:Aire de répartition du picard.PNG|160px|thumb|spread of '''Picard''' (Picard, Chti, Rouchi, etc.)]] Picard, like French, is one of the ''[[Oïl languages|langues d'oïl]]'' and belongs to the [[Gaul|Gallo]]-[[Romance languages|Roman]] family of languages. It consists of all the varieties used for writing ({{lang-la|scriptae}}) in the north of France from before 1000 (in the south of France at that time the [[Occitan language]] was used). Often, the ''langues d'oïl'' are referred to simply as [[Old French]]. Picard is phonetically quite different from the North-central ''langues d'oïl'', which evolved into modern French. Among the most notable traits, the evolution in Picard towards [[palatalization (sound change)|palatalization]] is less marked than in the central ''langues d'oïl'' in which it is particularly striking; {{IPA|/k/}} or {{IPA|/ɡ/}} before {{IPA|/j/}}, tonic {{IPA|/i/}} and {{IPA|/e/}}, as well as in front of tonic {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}} (the open {{IPA|/o/}} of the French ''p'''o'''rte'') in central Old French but not in Picard: * Picard ''keval'' ~ Old French ''cheval'' (horse; pronounced {{IPA|['''tʃ'''eval]}} rather than the modern {{IPA|['''ʃ'''əval]}}), from ''*kabal'' ([[vulgar Latin]] ''caballus''): retaining the original {{IPA|/k/}} in Picard before tonic {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}}. * Picard ''gambe'' ~ Old French ''jambe'' (leg; pronounced {{IPA|['''dʒ'''ambe]}} rather than the modern {{IPA|['''ʒ'''ɑ̃b]}} – {{IPA|[ʒ]}} is the ''ge'' sound in bei'''ge'''), from ''*gambe'' (vulgar Latin ''gamba''): absence of palatalization of {{IPA|/ɡ/}} in Picard before tonic {{IPA|/a/}} and {{IPA|/ɔ/}}. * Picard ''kief'' ~ Old French ''chef'' (leader), from ''*kaf'' ([[Latin]] ''caput''): less palatalization of {{IPA|/k/}} in Picard * Picard ''cherf'' ~ Old French ''cerf'' (stag; pronounced {{IPA|['''tʃ'''erf]}} and {{IPA|['''ts'''erf]}} respectively), from ''*kerf'' (Latin ''cervus''): simple palatalization in Picard, palatalization then fronting in Old French{{Citation needed|date=September 2010|reason=''cervus → *kárf → ʃerf'' seems implausible; more likely it is ''cervus → *serf → ʃerf''. Response: it's most likely to be cervus → tʃerf (cf. Italian cervo with tʃ) → ʃerf in Picard and cervus → tʃerf → tserf → serf in French}} The effects of palatalization can be summarised as this: * {{IPA|/k/}} and (tonic) {{IPA|/y/}}, {{IPA|/i/}} or {{IPA|/e/}}: Picard {{IPA|/tʃ/}} (written ''ch'') ~ Old French {{IPA|/ts/}} (written ''c'') * {{IPA|/k/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} + tonic {{IPA|/a/}} or {{IPA|/ɔ/}}: Picard {{IPA|/k/}} and {{IPA|/ɡ/}} ~ Old French {{IPA|/tʃ/}} and {{IPA|/dʒ/}}. There are striking differences, such as Picard ''cachier'' ('to hunt') ~ Old French ''chacier'', which later took the modern French form of ''chasser''. Because of the proximity of [[Paris]] to the northernmost regions of France, French (that is, the languages that were spoken in and around Paris) greatly influenced Picard and vice versa. The closeness between Picard and French made the former not always be recognised as a language in its own right, but rather a "distortion of French" as it is often viewed. Picard includes a variety of very closely related dialects. It is difficult to list them all accurately in the absence of specific studies on the dialectical variations, but these varieties can probably ''provisionally'' be distinguished {{Citation needed|date=April 2008}}: Amiénois, Vimeu-Ponthieu, Vermandois, Thiérache, Beauvaisis, "chtimi" (Bassin Minier, [[Lille]]), dialects in other regions near Lille (Roubaix, Tourcoing, Mouscron, Comines), "rouchi" ([[Valenciennes|Valenciennois]]) and Tournaisis, Borain, Artésien rural, Boulonnais. The varieties are defined by specific phonetic, morphological and lexical traits and sometimes by a distinctive literary tradition. ==Vocabulary== The majority of Picard words derive from [[Vulgar Latin]]. {| class="wikitable" |- ![[English language|English]] || Picard || French |- | |English || ''Inglé'' || Anglais |- | |Hello! || ''Bojour !'' or ''Bojour mes gins !'' (formal) or ''Salut ti z’aute !'' (informal) || Bonjour ([[Literal translation|lit.]]: Bonjour mes gens ! ''or'' Salut vous autres !) |- | |Good evening! || ''Bonsoèr !'' || Bonsoir |- | |Good night! || ''La boinne nuit !'' || Bonne nuit ! |- | |Goodbye! || ''À l’arvoïure !'' or ''À t’ervir !'' || Au revoir ! |- | |Have a nice day! || ''Eune boinne jornée !'' || Bonne journée ! |- | |Please/if you please || ''Sins vos komander'' (formal) or ''Sins t' komander'' (informal) || S'il vous plaît (lit: sans vous commander) |- | |Thank you || ''Merchi'' || Merci |- | |I am sorry || ''Pardon'' or ''Échtchusez-mi'' || Pardon ''or'' Excusez-moi |- | |What is your name? || ''Kmint qu’os vos aplez ?'' || Comment vous appelez-vous ? |- | |How much? || ''Combin qu’cha coûte ?'' || Combien ça coute ? |- | |I do not understand. || ''Éj n'comprinds poin.'' || Je ne comprends pas. |- | |Yes, I understand. || ''Oui, j' comprinds.'' || Oui, je comprends. |- | |Help! || ''À la rescousse !'' || À l'aide (lit.: À la rescousse !) |- | |Can you help me please? || ''Povez-vos m’aider, sins vos komander ?'' || Pouvez-vous m'aider, s'il vous plaît ? |- | |Where are the toilets? || ''D'ousqu'il est ech tchioér ?'' || Où sont les toillettes ? ([[Slang]]: Où sont les chiottes ?) |- | |Do you speak English? || ''Parlez-vos inglé ?'' || Parlez-vous anglais ? |- | |I do not speak Picard. || ''Éj n’pérle poin picard.'' || Je ne parle pas picard. |- | |I do not know. || ''Éj n’sais mie.'' || Je ne sais pas. (lit: Je ne sais [[Bread crumbs|mie]].) |- | |I know. || ''Éj sais.'' || Je sais. |- | |I am thirsty. || ''J’ai soé.'' (literally, "I have thirst") || J'ai soif. |- | |I am hungry. || ''J’ai fan.'' (literally, "I have hunger") || J'ai faim. |- | |How are you? / How are things going? / How is everything? || ''Comint qu’i va ?'' (formal) or ''Cha va t’i ?'' || Comment vas-tu ? ''or'' Ça va ? |- | |I am fine. || ''Cha va fin bien.'' || Ça va bien. |- | |Sugar ||''Chuque'' || Sucre |- | |Crybaby ||''Brayou'' || Pleurnicheur (lit: brailleur) |} ===Some phrases=== Many words are very similar to French, but a large number are totally specific to Picard—principally terms relating to [[mining]] or [[Agriculture|farming]]. Here are several typical phrases in Picard, accompanied by French and English translations: :'''J'ai prins min louchet por mi aler fouir min gardin.''' ::''J'ai pris ma bêche pour aller bêcher mon jardin.'' :::"I took my spade to go dig my garden." :'''Mi, à quate heures, j'archine eune bonne tartine.''' ::''Moi, à quatre heures, je mange une bonne tartine.'' :::"At four o'clock, I eat a good snack." :'''Quind un Ch'ti mi i'est à l'agonie, savez vous bin che qui li rind la vie ? I bot un d'mi.''' (''Les Capenoules'' (a music group)) ::''Quand un gars du Nord est à l'agonie, savez-vous bien ce qui lui rend la vie ? Il boit un demi.'' :::"When a northerner is dying, do you know what revives him? He drinks a pint." :'''Pindant l'briquet un galibot composot, assis sur un bos,''' :'''L'air d'eune musique qu'i sifflotot''' :'''Ch'étot tellemint bin fabriqué, qu'les mineurs lâchant leurs briquets''' :'''Comminssotent à's'mette à'l'danser (Edmond Tanière - ''La polka du mineur'')''' ::''Pendant le casse-croûte un jeune mineur composa, assis sur un bout de bois'' ::''L'air d'une musique qu'il sifflota'' ::''C'était tellement bien fait que les mineurs, lâchant leurs casse-croûte'' ::''Commencèrent à danser.'' :::"During lunch a young miner composed, seated on a piece of wood :::"The melody of a tune that he whistled :::"It was so well done that the miners, leaving their sandwiches, :::"Started to dance to it" (Edmond Tanière - ''La polka du mineur'', "The Miner's Polka") :'''I n'faut pas qu'ches glaines is cantent pus fort que ch'co.''' ::''Il ne faut pas que les poules chantent plus fort que le coq.'' :::"Hens must not sing louder than the rooster" (n. b. this saying really refers to men and women rather than poultry) :'''J' m'in vo à chlofe, lo qu'i n'passe poin d'caroche.''' ::''Je vais au lit, là où il ne passe pas de carrosse.'' :::"I go to bed where no car is running." :'''Moqueu d'gins''' ::''railleur'', ''persifleur'' (lit. ''moqueur des gens'') :::"someone who mocks or jeers at people" (compare ''gens'', which is French for "people") :'''Ramaseu d'sous''' ::''personne âpre au gain'' (lit. ''ramasseur de sous'') ::: "a greedy person" ===Numerals=== Cardinal numbers in Picard from 1 to 20 are as follows: * One: ''un'' (m) / ''eune'' (f) * Two: ''deus'' * Three: ''troés'' * Four: ''quate'' * Five: ''chonc'' * Six: ''sis'' * Seven: ''sèt'' * Eight: ''uit'' * Nine: ''neu'' * Ten: ''dis'' * Eleven: ''onze'' * Twelve: ''dousse'' * Thirteen: ''trèsse'' * Fourteen: ''quatore'' * Fifteen: ''tchinse'' * Sixteen: ''sèse'' * Seventeen: ''dis-sèt'' * Eighteen: ''dis-uit'' * Nineteen: ''dis-neu'' * Twenty: ''vint'' ==Use== [[File:Enseigne café picard Cayeux sur mer.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Picard language signage in [[Cayeux-sur-Mer]]]] Picard is not taught in [[France|French]] schools (apart from a few one-off and isolated courses) and is generally only spoken among friends or family members. It has nevertheless been the object of scholarly research at universities in [[Lille]] and [[Amiens]], as well as at [[Indiana University]].[http://www.indiana.edu/~frithome/faculty/frLing/auger.shtml Julie Auger], Department of French and Italian, Indiana University Since people are now able to move around France more easily than in past centuries, the different varieties of Picard are converging and becoming more similar. In its daily use, Picard is tending to lose its distinctive features and may be confused with regional French. At the same time, even though most Northerners can understand Picard today, fewer and fewer are able to speak it, and people who speak Picard as their [[first language]] are increasingly rare, particularly under 50.William Orem, [http://www.indiana.edu/~rcapub/v23n1/p16.html "The Princess & Picard"], ''Research & Creative Activity'', April 2000 Volume XXIII Number 1, Indiana University The 2008 film ''[[Bienvenue chez les Ch'tis]]'', starring comedian [[Dany Boon]], deals with Ch'ti language and culture and the perceptions of the region by outsiders. ==Written Picard== Today Picard is primarily a spoken language, but in the [[medieval]] period, there is a wealth of literary texts in Picard. However, Picard was not able to compete with French and was slowly reduced to the status of a regional language. A more recent body of Picard literature, written during the last two centuries, also exists. Modern written Picard is generally a transcription of the spoken language. For that reason, words are often spelled in a variety of different ways (in the same way that English and French were before they were standardised). One system of spelling for Picard words is very similar to that of French. It is undoubtedly the easiest for French speakers to understand but can also contribute the stereotype that Picard is only a corruption of French rather than a language in its own right. Various spelling methods have been proposed since the 1960s to offset the disadvantage and to give Picard a visual identity that is distinct from French. There is now a consensus, at least between universities, in favor of the written form known as '''Feller-Carton''' (based on the [[Walloon language|Walloon]] spelling system, which was developed by [[Jules Feller]], and adapted for Picard by Professor [[Fernand Carton]]). ==Learning Picard== Picard, although primarily a spoken language, has a body of written literature: poetry, songs ("[[P'tit Quinquin (song)|P'tit quinquin]]" for example), comic books, etc. A number of dictionaries and ''patois'' guides also exist (for French speakers): *[[René Debrie]], ''Le cours de picard pour tous - Eche pikar, bèl é rade (le Picard vite et bien). Parlers de l'Amiénois''. Paris, Omnivox, 1983 (+ 2 cassettes), 208p. * Alain Dawson, ''Le picard de poche''. Paris : Assimil, 2003, 192p. * Alain Dawson, ''Le "chtimi" de poche, parler du Nord et du Pas-de-Calais''. Paris : Assimil, 2002, 194p. * Armel Depoilly (A. D. d'Dérgny), ''Contes éd no forni, et pi Ramintuvries'' (avec lexique picard-français). Abbeville : Ch'Lanchron, 1998, 150p. * Jacques Dulphy, ''Ches diseux d'achteure : diries 1989''. Amiens : Picardies d'Achteure, 1992, 71p. + cassette * Gaston Vasseur, ''Dictionnaire des parlers picards du Vimeu (Somme), avec index français-picard (par l'équipe de Ch'Lanchron d'Abbeville)''. Fontenay-sous-Bois : SIDES, 1998 (rééd. augmentée), 816p. (11.800 termes) * Gaston Vasseur, ''Grammaire des parlers picards du Vimeu (Somme) - morphologie, syntaxe, anthropologie et toponymie''. 1996, 144p. ==See also== {{InterWiki|code=pcd}} {{wikiversity|Picard}} *[[Joret line]] *[[Languages of Europe]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Linguistic studies of Picard== *Villeneuve, Anne-José. 2013. In Rafael Núñez-Cedeño, Luís López, & Richard Cameron (eds.), ''Language Knowledge and Language Use: Selected Papers from LSRL 31''. Amsterdam: Benjamins. pp. 3–20. *Auger, Julie. 2003. “Picard parlé, picard écrit: comment s’influencent-ils l’un l’autre?”. In Jacques Landrecies & André Petit (eds.), "Le picard d’hier et d’aujourd’hui", special issue of ''Bien dire et bien Aprandre'', 21, Centre d'Études médiévales et Dialectales, Lille 3, pp. 17–32. *Auger, Julie. 2002. (with Jeffrey Steele) “A constraint-based analysis of intraspeaker variation: Vocalic epenthesis in Vimeu Picard”. In Teresa Satterfield, Christina Tortora, & Diana Cresti (eds.), ''Current Issues in Linguistic Theory: Selected Papers from the XXIXth Linguistic Symposium on the Romance Languages (LSRL), Ann Arbor 8–11 April 1999''. (eds.), ''Proceedings of the First International Conference on Language Variation in Europe (ICLaVE)''. Barcelona: Universitat Pompeu Fabra. pp. 14–24. ==External links== *[http://www.courrier-picard.fr/region/julie-auger-meme-s-ils-sont-proches-le-picard-ia0b0n457240 «Même s’ils sont proches, le picard n’est pas un mauvais français»] (in French) - an article about Julie Auger's linguistic research on Picard *[http://www.indiana.edu/~rcapub/v23n1/p16.html The Princess & Picard] - an essay about Picard from Indiana University, USA *[http://www.nordmag.com/culture/patois/patois.htm Qu'est-ce que le Picard?] (in French) - history of Picard *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1064932/ Bienvenue chez les Ch'tis] (in French)- a comedy about differences between northern and southern France. ===Audio=== ::http://ches.diseux.free.fr/sons/d85.mp3 ::http://ches.diseux.free.fr/diri/dir85.htm ::''[http://www.language-archives.org/language/pcd Centre de Ressources pour la Description de l'Oral - picard]'' (CRDO) ::''[http://cocoon.huma-num.fr/exist/crdo/rechercher.xql?langue=Picard COllections de COrpus Oraux Numériques - picard]'' (COCOON) {{Languages of France}} {{Languages of Belgium}} {{Languages of the Benelux}} {{Romance languages}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Picard Language}} [[Category:Oïl languages]] [[Category:Languages of France]] [[Category:Languages of Belgium]] [[Category:Walloon culture]] [[Category:Hainaut (province)]] [[Category:Culture of Picardy]] [[Category:Nord-Pas-de-Calais]]

[[File:The Scullery Maid (L'Ecureuse).jpg|thumb|right|300px|Oil painting of a scullery maid by [[Jean-Siméon Chardin]]]] In [[great house]]s, '''scullery maids''' were the lowest-ranked and often the youngest of the female [[domestic worker|domestic servants]]{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/modern-girl-too-soft-for-1900s-life-6302211.html|title=Modern girl too 'soft' for 1900s life|publisher=Evening Standard|language=English|author=Valentine Low|date=3 April 2002|accessdate=18 March 2017}} and acted as assistant to a [[kitchen maid (domestic worker)|kitchen maid]].''Children Living in Victorian Britain'', p. 13 https://books.google.com/books?id=0nhQojD3dN8C ==Description== The scullery maid reported (through the kitchen maid) to the [[cook (domestic worker)|cook]] or [[chef]]. Along with the junior kitchen-maid, the scullery maid did not eat at the communal servants' dining hall table, but in the kitchen in order to keep an eye on the food that was still cooking.''The Country House Kitchen: 1650-1900'', Pamela Sambrook and Peter Brears,1996, {{ISBN|0-7509-1642-7}}, p. 85. Duties of the scullery maid included the most physical and demanding tasks in the [[kitchen]] such as cleaning and scouring the floor, stoves, sinks, pots, and dishes. After scouring the plates in the [[scullery (room)|scullery]], she would leave them on racks to dry. The scullery maid also assisted in cleaning vegetables, plucking fowl, and scaling fish.''The Country House Kitchen'', p 85. ==''The Book of Household Management''==
The duties of the scullery-maid are to assist the cook; to keep the scullery clean, and all the metallic as well as earthenware kitchen utensils. The position of scullery-maid is not, of course, one of high rank, nor is the payment for her services large. But if she be fortunate enough to have over her a good kitchen-maid and clever cook, she may very soon learn to perform various little duties connected with cooking operations, which may be of considerable service in fitting her for a more responsible place. Now, it will be doubtless thought by the majority of our readers, that the fascinations connected with the position of the scullery-maid, are not so great as to induce many people to leave a comfortable home in order to work in a scullery. —[[Mrs. Beeton]], ''[[The Book of Household Management]]'', published 1861{{cite book |title=[[Mrs Beeton's Book of Household Management]] |last= Beeton |first=Isabella |authorlink=Isabella Beeton |year=1861 |publisher= S. O. Beeton Publishing |location=London |chapter=Chapter 4 - Introduction to Cookery |chapterurl=http://www.mrsbeeton.com/04-chapter4.html |accessdate=22 August 2011}}
==Additional duties== [[File:Dutch - Scullery Maid - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|Scullery maids cleaned metallic and earthenware kitchen utensils, but not fine [[porcelain|china]], stemware, [[crystal]] or plate [[silver]].]] The scullery maid provided hot water for the scullery, kitchen tasks, and household. In addition to her other tasks, the scullery maid had to keep the scullery clean by clearing away meat and vegetable garbage, scrubbing work tables, and swilling the floors. The water was carried through a drain outside the house.''The Country House Kitchen'', p. 87 Scullery maids would rarely have handled fine [[porcelain|china]], stemware, [[crystal]] or plate [[silver]]; these are cleaned by [[maid|housemaids]] and [[footman|footmen]]. Before the advent of central heating systems, scullery maids were required to light the fires on the kitchen stove and supply hot water for tea and washing. She performed these tasks in the morning before the cook came down to the kitchens.Edwardian Life: A Typical Day in the House https://www.pbs.org/manorhouse/edwardianlife/typical_day.html In a [[household]] with no [[between maid]], the scullery maid may also have waited on staff in the [[Servants' hall]], although this may have been assigned to another maid or a junior footman. In the days before the indoor [[water closet]] she may have been required to empty and clean the servants' [[chamber pot]]s as well.[http://www.theresestenzel.com/dinner.html Dinner is Served: The Role of English Servants] This work has, in modern (i.e. the nineteenth century) times, primarily been performed by women, but in [[Middle Ages|medieval]] households female domestics were relatively rare. A male servant performing the tasks described above would be called a '''scullion'''. In 1386, when the [[English Parliament]] requested the removal of certain of [[Richard II of England|Richard II]]'s ministers, the king infamously responded that he would not dismiss as much as a scullion from his kitchen at parliament's request.{{cite book|first=Nigel|last=Saul|authorlink=Nigel Saul|title=Richard II|edition=|publisher=Yale University Press|location=New Haven|year=1997|isbn=0-300-07003-9}} The root of the word scullery is the 1300–50 French word "escuelerie" (pronounced ''squillerye'' < equivalent to ''escuele'' -dish (< L scutella, dim. of scutra pan) + ''rie'' -ry.[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/scullery Scullery] reference.com ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.pbs.org/manorhouse/thepeople/ellen_duties.html Daily tasks] according to [[PBS]]. * [http://etext.library.adelaide.edu.au/b/beeton/isabella/household// The Book of Household Management], Mrs. [[Isabella Beeton]], originally published in 1861, this web edition published by eBooks@Adelaide, some rights reserved. * [http://www.hinchhouse.org.uk/ninth/ech.html Edwardian Life at Hitchingbrooke House: The Servant's Rules] * [http://logicmgmt.com/1876/house_tour/scullery.htm House Tour: The Scullery] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100414152542/http://www.olveston.co.nz/scullery The Olveston Experience: Images of a Scullery] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090516233043/http://www.panoramicmuseum.com/vt_cfarm/scullery/scullery.htm Victorian Scullery or Back Kitchen] * [http://www.kaufmanelson.com/pop_gallery.phtml?no=14_30 Image of a Scullery Maid With Fish and Fowl] {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scullery Maid}} [[Category:Maids]] [[Category:Obsolete occupations]] [[Category:Gendered occupations]] [[Category:Dishwashing]]

{{about|the current and future rise in sea level associated with [[global warming]]|general discussion of sea level|Sea level}} {{short description|The current long-term trend for sea levels to rise mainly in response to global warming.}} [[File:Evolution-of-GMSL-time-series-from-six-different-groups’.jpg|400px|thumb|Global mean sea level evolution from different datasets (1993–2018).]]
<!-- ATTENTION EDITORS - Before trying to shoehorn the title into the first sentence, remember that there is no requirement we have bold text in the first sentence. More important is natural easy reading. See [[WP:BOLDAVOID]] -->At least since 1880, the average global [[sea level]] has been rising, with about an {{convert|18|cm|in|abbr=on}} rise from 1897 to 1997.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Surveys in Geophysics|author=Bruce C. Douglas|title=Global Sea Rise: A Redetermination|volume=18|pages=279–292|year=1997|doi=10.1023/A:1006544227856|issue=2/3|bibcode = 1997SGeo...18..279D }}{{subscription required}}</ref> More precise satellite based data show about a {{convert|7.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} accelerating rise in sea level from 1993 to 2017.<ref name="WCRP2018">{{cite journal|journal=Earth System Science Data|year=2018|authors=WCRP Global Sea Level Budget Group|doi=10.5194/essd-10-1551-2018|title=Global sea-level budget 1993–present|url=https://www.earth-syst-sci-data.net/10/1551/2018/essd-10-1551-2018.html|quote=This corresponds to a mean sea-level rise of about 7.5 cm over the whole altimetry period. More importantly, the GMSL curve shows a net acceleration, estimated to be at 0.08mm/yr<sup>2</sup>.}}</ref>{{rp|1554}} This is due mostly to anthropogenic [[global warming]] that is driving the [[thermal expansion]] of seawater while melting land-based [[ice sheet]]s and [[glacier]]s.<ref name="Mengel" /> This trend is expected to accelerate during the 21st century.<ref>{{cite report | date = 2014 | title = Climate Change 2014 Synthesis Report Fifth Assessment Report, AR5 | url = http://ar5-syr.ipcc.ch/topic_summary.php | publisher = Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change | access-date = }} Under all RCP scenarios, the rate of sea level rise will very likely exceed the rate of 2.0 [1.7–2.3] mm/yr observed during 1971–2010</ref>{{rp|62}}
Projecting future sea level has always been challenging, due to our imperfect understanding of many aspects of the [[climate system]]. As [[climatology|climate research]] leads to improved [[climate model|computer models]], projections have consistently increased. <!-- ATTENTION EDITORS To do list, expand discussion of research (e.g., satellite telemetry, field research, modeling) and at climate models add sea level --> For example, in 2007 the high end of [[IPCC|Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] (IPCC) projections through 2099 was less than {{Convert|2|ft|}},<ref>{{citation |author= IPCC |chapter= Summary for Policymakers |title = Contribution of Working Group I to the Fourth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, 2007 |chapter-url= http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/ar4/syr/en/spm.html |at= page 13-14 }}"Models used to date do not include uncertainties in climate-carbon cycle feedback nor do they include the full effects of changes in ice sheet flow, because a basis in published literature is lacking."</ref> but in their 2014 report the high end was considered to be about {{Convert|3|ft|}}.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mooney |first1=Chris |title=Scientists keep upping their projections for how much the oceans will rise this century|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2017/04/26/scientists-keep-increasing-their-projections-for-how-much-the-oceans-will-rise-this-century |work=Washington Post}}</ref> A number of later studies have concluded that {{convert|2.0|to|2.7|m|round=each}} rise this century is "physically plausible".<ref>{{cite report | date = January 2017 | title = Global and Regional Sea Level Rise Scenarios for the United States | url =https://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/techrpt83_Global_and_Regional_SLR_Scenarios_for_the_US_final.pdf | publisher = National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration | edition = NOAA Technical Report NOS CO-OPS 083 | page = vi | access-date = 24 August 2018 }}"The projections and results presented in several peer-reviewed publications provide evidence to support a physically plausible GMSL rise in the range of 2.0 meters (m) to 2.7 m, and recent results regarding Antarctic ice-sheet instability indicate that such outcomes may be more likely than previously thought."</ref> The contributions to '''sea level rise''' since 1993, based on 2018 figures, divide into ocean [[thermal expansion]] (42%), melting of temperate glaciers (21%), [[Greenland]] (15%) and [[Antarctica]] (8%).<ref name="WCRP2018"></ref>
Sea level rise will not be the same at every location on earth, with some locations even getting a drop in sea levels. Local factors include [[tectonic]] effects, and [[subsidence]] of the land, tides, currents and storms. Sea level rise is expected to continue for centuries. Because of [[climate inertia|long response times]] for parts of the climate system, it has been estimated that we are committed to a sea-level rise of approximately {{convert|2.3|m|ft}} within the next 2,000 years for each [[Celsius]] degree of temperature rise.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Anders Levermann, Peter U. Clark, Ben Marzeion, Glenn A. Milne, David Pollard, Valentina Radic, and Alexander Robinson|date=13 June 2013|title=The multimillennial sea-level commitment of global warming|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/110/34/13745.abstract?sid=26fd1d37-7276-46e2-9192-0931e6ebf6ab|journal=PNAS|volume=110|issue=34|pages=13745–13750|bibcode=2013PNAS..11013745L|doi=10.1073/pnas.1219414110|pmc=3752235|pmid=23858443}}</ref>
Sea level rises [[Effects of climate change on humans|can considerably influence human populations]] in coastal and island regions and natural environments like [[marine ecosystem]]s.<ref name="wg1-5-5-1">{{Citation|author=Bindoff, N.L., J. Willebrand, V. Artale, A, Cazenave, J. Gregory, S. Gulev, K. Hanawa, C. Le Quéré, S. Levitus, Y. Nojiri, C.K. Shum, L.D. Talley and A.
